div.head: In-situ micro-diffraction study of the current -induced metal -insulator transition in VO2 materials
div.p: and associated devices: thermal (Peierls) versus electronic (Mott-Hubbard) phase transition mechanisms.

The purpose of the present experiment was to map out the spatial distribution of the metallic (quadratic) and insulating (monoclinic) phases of VO2 films epitaxially grown on sapphire substrates during the metal-insulator transition. The materials have been patterned with electrodes and mounted on a compact Peltier stage so as to monitor in-situ the diffraction signal and the electrical properties as a function of both temperature and injected current.

The materials have been characterized using laboratory XRD prior to experiments, and a clear diffraction signal from VO2 was observed, even for the thinnest films. Surprisingly, at the BM32 beamline in the micro-Laue configuration (beam size 0.5x0.5 µm²), absolutely no diffraction signal could be recorded from the VO2 films. After 2 days, we aborted the run.
The reasons for this lack of signal is unclear (especially considering that a signal is observed on a laboratory diffractometer with a large conventional beam) and is still investigated.
